sn11.10:4.2: “Once upon a time, mendicants, several seers who were ethical, of good character, settled in leaf huts by the ocean.
sn11.10:4.3: Now at that time a battle was fought between the gods and the demons.
sn11.10:4.5: ‘The gods are principled, the demons are unprincipled.
sn11.10:4.6: We may be at risk from the demons.
sn11.10:4.7: Why don’t we approach Sambara, Lord of Demons, and beg him for a pledge of safety.’
sn11.10:4.9: Then, as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm,
sn11.10:4.11: those seers vanished from those leaf huts by the ocean and reappeared in Sambara’s presence.
sn11.10:4.12: Then those seers addressed Sambara in verse:
sn11.10:5.2: to beg for a pledge of safety.
sn11.10:5.3: For you can give them what you wish,
sn11.10:6.3: though you beg me for your safety,
sn11.10:7.1: ‘Though we beg you for our safety,
sn11.10:7.3: This is what we get from you:
sn11.10:7.4: may endless peril come to you!
sn11.10:8.1: Whatever kind of seed you sow,
sn11.10:8.2: that is the fruit you reap.
sn11.10:8.3: A doer of good gets good,
sn11.10:8.4: a doer of bad gets bad.
sn11.10:8.5: You have sown your own seed, friend,
sn11.10:9.1: Then those seers, having cursed Sambara,
sn11.10:9.2: as easily as a strong person would extend or contract their arm,
sn11.10:9.4: vanished from Sambara’s presence and reappeared in those leaf huts by the ocean.
sn11.10:9.5: But after being cursed by the seers, Sambara woke in alarm three times that night.”
